learning_objectives.objective: Define key length and list NIST-recommended minimums for symmetric (e.g., AES-128 for 128-bit security) and asymmetric keys (e.g., RSA 3072 for 128-bit security).
Explain the relationship between key length and security strength, including how security strength (bits of security) differs from raw key length due to algorithm-specific attacks.
Select appropriate key lengths for given cryptographic use cases, such as choosing AES-256 for high-security data in transit.
Compare key length requirements across algorithm types (symmetric vs. asymmetric) using NIST SP 800-57 tables.
Critique a sample policy for compliance with NIST SP 800-57 and SP 800-131A, identifying gaps in acceptable vs. legacy/disallowed algorithms.
Formulate a key length policy for an organization, incorporating cryptoperiods, security lifetimes, and future-proofing against quantum threats.
